https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/What_Is_Life%3F This is a very interesting book, especially in explaining the nature of life as a system of self-sustaining disequilibrium. In particular, from Chapters 6 and 7, it follows that using another life to reduce one's own entropy is essentially an attempt to create a perpetual motion machine that maintains its nonequilibrium state at its expense. The closer to each other in structure living organisms that eat each other for survival, the more it looks like creating a perpetual motion machine. Cannibalism is a direct attempt to violate the second law of thermodynamics for a given animal species and threatens with its self-destruction.

The use of the word "energy" is risky. Energy is a system's capability to do work and cause change. If energy is useless, then it cannot cause change and is not energy. A universe that is infinitely hot in every point has no change, thus zero energy. A universe that is 273 degrees at every point on one half and -273 degrees on the other half has energy, and be harnessed to do things.

This video says energy in a dam can never be reused, but evaporation eventually redeposits water which reflows a dam. Say what you will but that statement was invalid.

You can say the dam reflows only because the sun drove evaporation and the sun will die...

1 ) and yet, the sun was formed via gravitation alone, which performed the work to gather energy.

2) and yet, the sun dying will cause more complex atoms in the super nova, not less. These atoms will never decay, they will only gain complexity.

3) you can say the "expanding universe" will spread these atoms so thin they will cease to be atoms, and yet there is no evidence this spread is occurring at the quantum level. the planck length is always identical, the speed of light is always measured the same, so the expansion, if it is occuring, is happening between matter, not within matter, the case for it occurring within matter has been observationally disproven already. also, the red shift is the only evidence for "an expanding universe" we don't understand "dark" matter or energy, at all, which may totally account for the red shift in some other way

4) since matter isn't expanding inside itself (it's never been observed, even though we can measure diameters of atoms and strength of forces), the worst that can happen is "heat death" (in fact, this heat death is Sean Carol's interpretation), yet, an atom frozen is technically more order, not less. heat death confuses order (entropy) with energy (not entropy, but associated with it, since more energy equals more disorder, since it vibrates atoms). Paradoxically, and missed in the heat death argument for entropy and applying the 2nd thermodynamic law across the universe, is the fact that a frozen, or "heat death" universe is all a solid, as in, more order, not less.

5) and yet, it is claimed that "this is not a solid", because the atoms will be spread across the whole universe, however, the order is increased because of the lack of temperature; the atom behavior is that of a solid, regardless of what you call it, and defies the 2nd law, regardless of what you call it.

6) the Earth itself generates it's own energy from the compression of mater from gravity alone. geologists explain friction alone generates massive amounts of energy and heat within the Earth and is responsible for the molten core, and that even if the sun stopped shining, "the Earth's core would remain molten because of compression and friction". and even cosmology explains europa and Io are the way they are from energy generated from gravity. and even Pluto, which has a surface temperature of almost absolute zero, has surface activity signs and a molten core, even though it recieves not nearly enough energy from the sun to account for this.

The laws of thermodynamics have been rewritten already to account for quantum chromodynamics. You can simply read wikipedia on this or look up "thermodynamic laws must be rewritten"...

What? No Boltzmann brains?

There's also a paradox about the notion of equilibrium: if equilibrium is indeed a state where the properties of the system seize to change then it is impossible to get into equilibrium - as to get into a steady state, taken together with time reversibility would mean that it is possible (even if improbable, but that's entirely irrelevant for this point) to move away from the steady state - which implies that the steady state is not steady after all.
The paradox resolves itself quite naturally when we allow for spontaneous, but highly improbable, 'violations' of the 2nd law of thermodynamics. (In fact they are not even violations, they are pretty much allowed within the framework of thermodynamics when a theory that works well at microscopic levels also exists).

So, you almost never get tepid tea warming up whilst generating an ice-cube.

Our universe will end up dark, cold, and void of any and all matter. It will keep expanding at ever increasing rates until random quantum fluctuations and quantum tunnelling generate a new big bang (according to wikipedia, "Timeline of the far future").

This is estimated to happen in 10 to the power of 10, to the power of 10, to the power 56... years from now.

Just worth noting real fast, because at the beginning it makes it sound worse than it is, while the Earth is radiating a bit less energy out than it receives, as its temperature increases, the amount of radiation it emits itself will increase. It's a factor of 1:4. (Blackbody radiation) So this limits the total heat increase possible, because the sun's energy isn't increasing, and we aren't able to blanket the planet much further. Only a bit.

It's the estimated climate sensitivity to CO2. It depends on other positive and negative feedbacks beyond blackbody radiation, but that one is one of the more critical negative feedbacks. ESC depends on a doubling of CO2 in the atmosphere, as it becomes saturated fast. It's not a linear increase to the heat trapping effect. I.E. 200 to 400 ppm has the same heat trapping potency as 400 to 1,600 ppm.

Just worth noting it in context. I think climate change is important to talk about but it is so often either dramatically overstated, or dramatically understated.. let's actually be realistic instead of going to extremes.

This is the best explanation of entropy I've ever seen.
Another example: A soda can is full of carbonated soda. When it's opened, the carbonation will slowly decrease until the soda is no longer fizzy. Putting it in a box with all of the CO2 and pressurizing the box wouldn't make the CO2 go back into the soda. The CO2 has gone from a low entropy state inside the soda, to a high entropy state as a gas outside of the soda.
